I tried quite a bit with that lemma, but I concluded that since ‚àÄ i, 1 ‚â§ i ‚Üí i ‚â§ n ‚Üí ‚Äñiterated_fderiv ùïú i f x‚Äñ ‚â§ D^i did not hold for i=1 when f = ‚Äñx‚Äñ^2 then it would not really work.
But since I have ‚àÉ (C : ‚Ñù), ‚àÄ (x : ?m_1), ‚Äñ‚Üë‚Äñx‚Äñ ^ k * cexp (-a * ‚Üë‚Äñx‚Äñ ^ 2)‚Äñ ‚â§ C, I can make the proof work as long as I can show ‚Äñfderiv ‚Ñù (Œª (y : E'), ‚Üë‚Äñy‚Äñ ^ 2) x‚Äñ is bounded by some form of summation a * ‚Äñx‚Äñ^k, so for me it does not matter how big k or a is :)
The D is allowed to depend on x, but not on i.
oh, I thought D had to be a constant? :)
if you look at the statement, first you have to give the theorem an x and then an D, so if you apply that theorem you choose D according to you choice of x.
Constants are overrated and usually depend on something :big_smile:
